column1: Tabriz (Persian: تبریز‎ [tæbˈɾiːz] (listen); Azerbaijani: تبریز‎) is the most populous city in northwestern Iran
column2: one of the historical capitals of Iran and the present capital of East Azerbaijan Province. It is the fifth-most-populous city in Iran. In the Quru River valley in Iran's historic Azerbaijan region between long ridges of volcanic cones in the Sahand and Eynali mountains
column3: Tabriz's elevation ranges between 1
column4: 350 and 1
column5: 600 metres (4
column7: 250 ft) above sea level. The valley opens up into a plain that gently slopes down to the eastern shores of Lake Urmia
column8: 60 kilometres (37 miles) to the west. With cold winters and temperate summers
column9: Tabriz is considered a summer resort. It was named World Carpet Weaving City by the World Crafts Council in October 2015 and Exemplary Tourist City of 2018 by the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation.With a population of over 1.7 million (2016)
column10: Tabriz is the largest economic hub and metropolitan area in Northwest Iran. The population is overwhelmingly Azerbaijani
column11: though Persian is spoken by residents as a second language. Tabriz is a major heavy industries hub for automobiles
column15: textiles and cement production industries. The city is famous for its handicrafts
column16: including hand-woven rugs and jewellery. Local confectionery
column18: dried nuts and traditional Tabrizi food are recognised throughout Iran as some of the best. Tabriz is also an academic hub and a site for some of the most prestigious cultural institutes in Northwest Iran.

column1: Tabriz contains many historical monuments
column2: representing Iran's architectural transition throughout its deep history. Most of Tabriz's preserved historical sites belong to Ilkhanid
column3: Safavid and Qajar. Among these sites is the grand Bazaar of Tabriz
column4: which is designated a World Heritage Site. From the early modern era
column5: Tabriz was pivotal in the development
column6: movement and economy of its three neighboring regions; namely the Caucasus
column7: Eastern Anatolia and Central Iran. In modern era city played a vital role in the history of Iran. As the country's closest hub to Europe
column8: many aspects of early modernisation in Iran began in Tabriz. Prior to forced ceding of the Qajar dynasty's Caucasian territories to Imperial Russia
column9: following two Russo-Persian Wars in the first half of the 19th century
column10: Tabriz was at the forefront of Iranian rule over its Caucasian territories. Until 1925
column11: the city was the traditional residence of the Qajar crown princes.

column1: == Etymology ==
According to some sources
column2: including Encyclopædia Britannica
column3: the name Tabriz derives from tap-riz
column4: from the many thermal springs in the area. Other sources claim that in AD 246
column5: to avenge his brother's death
column6: king Tiridates II of Armenia repelled Ardashir I of the Sassanid Empire and changed the name of the city from Shahistan to Tauris
column7: deriving from "ta-vrezh" ("this revenge" in Grabar). In AD 297
column8: it became the capital of Tiridates III
column10: this story has a popular origin and no ancient source has recorded such event. This is based on accounts of Vardan Areveltsi
column11: a 13th-century Armenian historian. The Cambridge History of Iran points to a connection between the "ancient stronghold of Tarui-Tarmakisa" (or Tarwi-Tarwakisa)
column12: which existed in VIII century BC
column14: with Ernst Emil Herzfeld's Archaeological History of Iran also directly equating "Tarwakisa" with Tabriz. Thus
column15: some researchers believe that Tabriz may be considered a pre-Iranian toponym.

column1: == History ==
=== Early history ===

The early history of Tabriz is not well-documented. The earliest civilization signs in the city belongs to an Iron Age grave yard of 1st millennium B.C. which were unearthed in late 1990s in northern side of Blue Mosque. The city also inscribed as old as 714 B.C. on as Tarui or Tauris
column2: on the Assyrian King Sargon II's epigraph in 714 BC.Egyptologist David Rohl suggested that the legendary Garden of Eden was near Tabriz. Archaeologist Eric H. Cline commented on Rohl's views
column3: writing that "his suggestions have not caught on with the scholarly establishment. His argument is not helped by the fact that it depends upon speculations regarding the transmission of place-names for both the various rivers and nearby related areas from antiquity to the present. In the end
column4: while Rohl’s suggestion is not out of the question
column5: it seems no more probable than any other hypothesis
column6: and less likely than those suggested by Speiser
column8: and Sauer."Since the earliest documented history of Tabriz
column9: it has been chosen as the capital for several rulers commencing from Atropates era and his dynasty. It is likely the city has been destroyed multiple times either by natural disasters or by the invading armies. The earliest elements of the present Tabriz are claimed to be built either at the time of the early Sassanids in the 3rd or 4th century AD
column10: or later in the 7th century. The city used to be called T'awrēš in Middle Persian.

column1: === From the Arab conquest to the Constitutional Revolution ===
After the Muslim conquest of Iran
column2: the Arabian Azd tribe from Yemen resided in Tabriz. The development of post-Islamic Tabriz began as of this time. The Islamic geographer Yaqut al-Hamawi says that Tabriz was a village before Rawwad from the tribe of Azd arrive at Tabriz. In 791 AD
column3: Zubaidah
column4: the wife of Abbasid caliph Harun al-Rashid
column5: rebuilt Tabriz after a devastating earthquake and beautified the city so much as to obtain the credit for having been its founder.In the ramadan of 1208
column7: as well as its adjacent cities and territories were conquered by the Kingdom of Georgia under Tamar the Great
column8: as a response to the massacre of 12
column9: 000 Christians in the Georgian-controlled city of Ani on Easter day by Muslims. In nearby Ardebil
column10: conquered by the Georgians as well
column12: 000 Muslims were killed. The Georgians then pushed further
column13: taking Khoy and Qazvin along the way.After the Mongol invasion
column14: Tabriz came to eclipse Maragheh as the later Ilkhanid Mongol capital of Azerbaijan until it was sacked by Timur in 1392.

column1: Chosen as a capital by Abaqa Khan
column2: fourth ruler of the Ilkhanate
column3: for its favored location in the northwestern grasslands
column5: his successor Ghazan Khan made it the chief administrative centre of an empire stretching from Anatolia to the Oxus River and from the Caucasus to the Indian Ocean. Under his rule
column6: new walls were built around the city
column8: educational facilities
column9: and caravansarais were erected to serve traders travelling on the ancient Silk Road. The Byzantine Gregory Choniades is said to have served as the city's Orthodox bishop during this time.In the 13th century
column10: many western expediters who visit Tabriz on their way to the east were amazed by the richness of the city
column11: its magnificent buildings and its institutions.Marco Polo
column12: who travelled through the Silk Road and passed Tabriz about 1275
column13: described it as: "a great city surrounded by beautiful and pleasant gardens. It is excellently situated so the goods brought to here coming from many regions. Latin merchants specially Genevis go there to buy the goods that come from foreign lands."From 1375 to 1468
column14: Tabriz was the capital of Qara Qoyunlu state in Azerbaijan
column15: until defeat of Qara Qoyunlu ruler
column16: Jahan Shah by Ag Qoyunlu warriors. Ag Qoyunlus selected Tabriz as their capital from 1469 to 1501. Some of the existing historical monuments including the Blue Mosque belong to the Qara Qoyunlu period.

column2: Shah Ismail I entered Tabriz and proclaimed it the capital of his Safavid state. In 1514
column3: after the Battle of Chaldiran
column4: Tabriz was temporarily occupied by the Ottomans. Tabriz was retaken by Iranian forces and it remained the capital of Safavid Iranian empire until 1548. In that year Shah Tahmasp I transferred it to Qazvin to avoid the growing threat of the Ottoman army to his capital.

column1: Between 1585 and 1603
column2: Tabriz was under occupation by Ottomans. After it was retaken by the Safavids under Abbas I of Persia
column3: the city grew as a major commerce centre
column4: conducting trade with the Ottoman Empire
column5: Russia
column6: and the Caucasus. Tabriz was occupied and sacked by Ottoman Murad IV in 1635
column8: before being returned to Persia in the Treaty of Zohab in 1639.

column2: a large earthquake shocked Tabriz
column3: killing about eighty thousand of its residents. The devastation continued in 1724–1725
column4: when the city was invaded by an Ottoman army. During this round of invasion
column5: the Ottomans imprisoned many in Tabriz and killed about two hundred thousand residents. The city was subsequently retaken by the Iranian army

The crown prince normally served as governor of Azerbaijan province as well. Some of the most important events in this period were the wars between Qajar Iran and neighbouring Imperial Russia. Prior to the forced cession of Iran's Caucasian territories—comprising what is now Georgia
column17: and Armenia—to Imperial Russia following the two Russo-Persian Wars of the first half of the 19th century

column23: who marched into the city with 3
column24: 000 soldiers. After Abbas Mirza and Ivan Paskevich signed the peace treaty

column27: Russian political and military influence remained a major force in Tabriz and north-northwestern Iran even until the fall of the Russian empire in the early 20th century. After the retreat of the Russian army
column30: launched a modernization scheme from Tabriz
column31: during which he introduced Western-style institutions
column33: installed the first regular postal service
column34: and undertook military reforms in the city. He also began a rebuilding campaign and established a modern taxation system.

column1: === Contemporary era ===
Thanks to the geographical closeness to the West and to communications with nearby countries' enlightenment movements
column2: Tabriz became the centre of the Iranian Constitutional Revolution movements between 1905 and 1911
column3: which led to the establishment of a parliament in Iran and the formation of a constitution. Sattar Khan and Bagher Khan
column4: two Tabrizi reformists who led Tabriz people's solidarity against the absolute monarchy
column5: had a great role in achievement to the goals of Iran's constitutional revolution. In 1909
column6: Tabriz was occupied by the Russian forces. Four months after the constitutional revolution's success
column8: the Russians reinvaded Tabriz. After crushing the local resistance by invading Russian troops
column9: they started suppressing the constitutional revolutionaries and residents of the city. Following the invasion
column11: 200 of Tabriz residents. As a result of the campaign
column12: Tabriz was occupied by the Russian forces between 1911 and 1917.

column1: From the very start of World War I
column2: Iran declared neutrality. When the war erupted on a full scale
column3: Tabriz and much of northwestern-northern Iran had already been de facto occupied by Russia for several years. In later years of World War I
column4: the Ottoman troops intervened and took control of the city by defeating the Russian troops stationed there. By this time
column5: the Ottoman army led by Enver Pasha threatened the whole Russian army in the Caucasus region. Russian troops recaptured the city from the Ottomans at a later stage of the war. By escalation of the revolution in Russia
column6: the Russian armies in Iranian Azerbaijan were evacuated
column7: and the actual power passed into the hands of the local committee of the democrat party
column8: with Ismail Nawbari at its head. Following Russia's retreat
column9: the Ottomans captured the city once again for a few months until the decisive end of the war
column10: and retreated thereafter. After World War I
column11: a new era in the county's history began. Reza Shah
column12: brigadier-general of the Persian Cossack Brigade
column13: declared himself the king of the country following a coup d'état. He started with promises of modernization programs in Iran which was concentrated on the unification of the country
column14: under the idea of one country
column15: one nation. This included centralization of the power and imposing restrictions on the local culture
column18: and the city of Tabriz. The modernization and nationalization plan of Reza Shah continued until the surge of World War II.

column1: At the final year of the World War II despite the declaration of the neutrality by the Iranian government
column2: the country was occupied by the allied forces. The allied forces then urged Reza Shah to abdicate and installed his son Mohammad Reza as the new king of the country. The postwar situation was further complicated by Soviet aid to set up a local government called Azerbaijan People's Government in Northwest Iran
column3: having Tabriz as its capital. The new Soviet-backed local government was run by Ja'far Pishevari and held power for one year starting from 1946. Pishevari's government gave more freedom to speech and education in Azerbaijani language and promoted local cultural heritage and gained some popularity among the residents. However
column4: after the withdrawal of Soviet forces
column5: Pishevari's limited armed forces were crushed by the Imperial Iranian army and the Iranian government retook control of the city. One of the major establishments in the period of Pishevari's government was opening of the University of Tabriz which played a major role in the later political movements and protests in the region.

column1: For the next 30 years
column2: after the collapse of Azerbaijan's autonomous government
column3: Tabriz enjoyed a stable era until the revolution in 1979. During this period the city received many of investors in its industries and had transformed into a heavy industries hub in the northwest of Iran. The need for a strong workforce increased immigration from all around Azerbaijan toward Tabriz. During this era and because of the continuous policy of the government centralization in Tehran as well as changes in communication and transportation
column4: the city lost its historical dominance in favour of being the gate for reform and modernization in the country.

column1: Starting with 1978 and with the heat of the Iranian Revolution
column2: revolutionary movements of some of Tabriz residents played a major role in the revolution. After the revolution
column3: the residents of the city were unsatisfied with the outcome
column4: mainly because of the ignorance of the revolutionary government about the rights of the Azerbaijani minority. Another major source of dissatisfaction was the support of most of Iranian Azerbaijanis including Tabriz residents from a more liberal cleric
column5: Grand Ayatollah Shariatmadari
column6: who was against the content of the new constitution which was mixing religion and state together. The unrest in the city calmed down after brutal crush of the protesters in Tabriz and after house arrest of Shariatmadari.

column1: In the 1980s
column2: due to the Iran–Iraq War
column3: like the rest of the country
column4: most of the construction and development projects in the city were stopped in order to fund the war costs. In addition to the indirect effects of the war
column5: city's industrial zone
column6: especially the oil refinery was also a major target for airstrikes by Iraqi's air forces because of the closeness to the Iraqi borderlines
column7: and their strategic roles in the country's economy. With the escalation of the war
column8: the attacks turned to War of the Cities and the air attacks later turned into the random strikes on the residential areas of the city in the later phase of the war.In recent years
column9: Tabriz is much more stable and the new developments in the city are rapidly changing the face of the city.

column1: === Capital of Iran ===
Tabriz was chosen as the capital by several rulers commencing from the time of Atropates. It was the capital of the Ilkhanate (Mongol) dynasty since 1265. During the Ghazan Khan era
column2: who came into power in 1295
column3: the city reached its highest splendour. The later realm stretched from the Amu Darya in the East to the Egypt borders in the West and from the Caucasus in the North to the Indian Ocean in the South. It was again the capital of Iran during the Qara Qoyunlu dynasty from 1375 to 1468 and then during the Ag Qoyunlu within 1468–1501. Finally
column4: it was capital of the Iranian Empire in the Safavid period from 1501 until their defeat in 1555.During the Qajar dynasty
column5: Tabriz was used as residence centre of Iranian Crown Prince (1794–1925).

column1: === Excavation sites ===

column2: during a construction project at the north side of the Blue Mosque (Part of Silk Road Project)
column3: an ancient graveyard was revealed. This was kept secret until a construction worker alerted the authorities. Radiocarbon analysis by Allameh Tabatabai University has shown the background of the graves to be more than 3800 years old. A museum of these excavations including the Blue Mosque was opened to the public in 2006.

column1: The other excavation site is in Abbasi Street at the site of Rab'-e Rashidi
column2: which was the location for an academic institution since approximately

column1: 700 years ago. It was established in Ilkhanid period.
=== City of Firsts ===
The City of Firsts or city of pioneers is an unofficial motto for Tabriz
column2: a major city and provincial capital in north west of Iran. The motto is given because of the pioneering role of the city in modernization signs in Iran and its leading role in movement toward the formation of modern Iran.

column1: Firsts of Tabriz in the Iranian History:
Printing Industry: The first publication house was founded by Prince Abbas Mirza in Tabriz
column2: And 12 years later a second publication was established in Tehran.

column1: == Geography ==
=== Topography ===
Tabriz is located in northwest of Iran in East Azerbaijan province between Eynali and Sahand mountains in a fertile area in shore of Aji River and Ghuri River.
The local area is earthquake-prone and during its history
column2: the city has been devastated and rebuilt several times.

column1: === Climate ===
Tabriz has a Continental climate with regular seasons (Köppen Dsa) bordering cold semi-arid climate (Köppen BSk). The annual precipitation is around 320 millimetres (13 in)
column2: a good deal of which falls as snow during the winter months and rain in spring and autumn. The city enjoys mild and fine climate in spring
column3: dry and semi-hot in summer
column4: humid and rainy in autumn and snowy cold in winter. The average annual temperature is 12.6 °C (54.7 °F). Cool winds blow from east to west mostly in summer.

column1: === Environment pollution ===

Air pollution is one of the major environmental issues in Tabriz. Air pollution is due to increase of a number of cars in the commuting in the city and the polluting industries such as thermal power plants
column2: petrochemical complexes and the oil refinery in the west of the city
column3: air pollution levels increased continuously in the second half of the 20th century. With a mandate of national environmental codes by heavy industries
column4: industrial air pollution is reduced in recent years. However
column5: the air quality in the city is far away from world norms for clean air.

column1: An immediate environmental threat is the shrinkage and drying out of the Lake Urmia located in outskirts of Western Tabriz. The lake has faced a grave crisis since the late 20th century. Water depth reduction
column2: increasing water salinity to saturation level and the appearance of vast salt fields around the lake
column3: are alarming indications of gradual total desiccation of a unique ecosystem. This occurred due to global warming and ever-increasing demands for inadequate freshwater sources in the basin. It is feared in the near future low-lying clouds of airborne salt and minerals may hover over large areas around the lake
column4: posing serious health hazards.

column1: == Governance ==
Authority for the city lies with the Mayor
column2: who is elected by a municipal board. The municipal board is periodically elected by the city's residents. The Municipal central office is located at the Tabriz Municipality Palace.

column1: === Historic municipal districts ===
Tabriz is divided into 12 municipal districts. Each municipal district retains a number of the older neighborhoods that are of cultural and historical interest.
=== Modern municipal districts ===
This is table of modern Tabriz districts.
== Demographics ==
According to an official 2016 census
column2: the population of Tabriz is 1
column4: 033. The majority of the city's population are Azerbaijani people
column5: followed by Persians
column8: and other People of Caucasus.

column1: === Language ===
The predominant language spoken in Tabriz is Azerbaijani language (Azerbaijani people call it Türkü or Türki language)
column2: which is a Turkic language mutually intelligible with modern Turkish dialects. The language has a strong Iranian superstratum since it has been in close contact with the Persian language for many centuries. Similar to the other parts of Iran
column3: the official language is Persian and the most inhabitants have native or near-native knowledge of Persian language
column4: which is the major medium of education.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: the Iranian constitution respects the right to speak and have limited educational facilities in other native languages
column3: including Azerbaijani. For the first time
column4: an academic program on Azerbaijani language opened at the University of Tabriz in 1999. Other than Azerbaijani
column5: there is a notable minority of Armenian speakers and a smaller minority of Assyrian Neo-Aramaic speakers.

column1: It is believed that before the gradual increase and dominance of Azerbaijani language in the area
column2: other Iranian languages similar to Persian were spoken in Azerbaijan and Tabriz. The 13th-century manuscript Safina-yi Tabriz has poems in what its Tabriz-born author has called the Tabrizi language (Zabān-e-Tabrizi) which is similar to Persian.

column1: === Religion ===
After being crowned at Tabriz in 1501
column2: Shah Ismail I announced the Twelver branch of Shia Islam as the official religion of the Safavid Empire. As a result of this royal order
column3: the most Sunni population of Tabriz converted to Shia.

column1: Currently
column2: the majority of people are followers of Shia Islam. The city has a visible Armenian Apostolic minority who follow Christianity. There used to be a small Jewish community
column3: but most of them have moved to Tehran. There is a small
column4: embattled community of the Baháʼí Faith in the city.

column7: and illumination movements. In old times the city notables supported poets and writers by organizing periodical meetings. Within its long history

column1: === Music ===
A century-long autocratic nation-building policy of central governments in Iran has succeeded in cultural assimilation in the favour of a government-sanctioned culture. As a result
column2: Tabriz
column3: by the turn of the 20th century had nearly become devoid of its once characteristic cultural identity. Thanks to the more liberal policies of the Khatami era (1998–2006)
column4: a cultural renaissance took place and the local music was revitalized.

column1: The traditional Azeri music is divided into two distinct types
column2: the music of "ashugh" and the "mugham". Mugham
column3: despite its similarity to Persian classical music
column4: was not common among Iranian Azeris. In recent years
column5: however
column6: mugham is gaining popularity among the educated middle-class young generation. For instance
column8: from Tabriz
column9: was the laureate of Mugam contest 2007.

column1: The ashugh music had survived in a mountainous region of Qaradağ and presently is identified as the characteristic form of music in all Azerbaijan. The ashugh music
column2: throughout its long history
column3: had been associated with nomadic life in mountainous regions and used to be dismissed as back-country folklore. The recent identity renaissance of Azeri speaking people has elevated the status of Ashughs as the guardians of national culture. The newfound unprecedented popularity and frequent concerts and performances in urban settings have resulted in rapid innovative developments aiming to enhance the urban-appealing aspects of these ashugh performances. The main factor for these developments was the opening of academic style music classes in Tabriz by master Ashugs
column4: such as Aşiq Imran Heydəri.

column1: Ashugs (Aşiq in Azeri language stemmed from the Arabic word for lover) were travelling bards who sang and played saz
column2: an eight or ten string plucking instrument in the form of a long-necked lute. Their roots can be traced back to at least the 7th century according to the Turkic epic Dede Korkut. Naturally
column3: the music has evolved in the course of the grand migration and ensuing feuds with the original inhabitants the acquired lands. Still
column4: the essence of the original epics
column5: i.e. metamorphic description of life in pastoral terms with direct reference to the mountainous landscape
column6: persists to the present time. The characteristic aspect of the Ashugh music is its frequent allusions to a mountain with the intention of arousing an emotional state with a tone of mild melancholy in a listener. The first verses of a contemporary Ashug song
column8: may well represent the essence of Ashugh music may clarify the said statement.

duman səlamət qal dağ səlamət qal (Farewell to the Mist and to the mountain)

column1: === Painting ===
Tabrizian style painting was shaped in the era of Ilkhanids
column2: Kara Koyunlu and the Safavids. The paintings date back to the early 14th century and show significant influence from Chinese and Chinese-influenced pictures. Over the years Tabriz became the centre of the famous school of Persian miniature painting. A fascinating fictional account of "Tabrizian style" painting in the Safavids era is narrated by Orhan Pamuk in My Name Is Red.

column1: === Cuisine ===
Famous dishes in Tabriz include:
Aash is a kind of soup prepared with bouillon
column2: various vegetables
column3: carrots
column4: noodles and spices.

column1: Abgoosht or Shorva (آب‌گوشت) is a hearty soup made of mutton (sheep meat) and chickpeas. It has been cooked in Iran for many years and
column2: until recently
column3: was the main dish of most families in Tabriz.

column1: Chelow kabab
column2: kebab and roasted tomatoes (and roasted hot peppers occasionally) served on a plate of steamed rice
column3: is the national dish of Iran. Tabriz is famous for the quality of its chelow kabab.

column1: Dolma is a traditional delicious Azerbaijani food. It is prepared with eggplant
column2: capsicum
column3: tomato or zucchini filled with a mixture of meat
column4: split pea
column5: onion and various spices.

column1: Garniyarikh (meaning "the torn abdomen" in Azeri) is a kind of dolma filled with meat
column2: garlic
column3: almonds and spices.

column1: Tabriz köfte is a special recipe from Tabriz with the appearance of big meatballs
column2: which are prepared with a mixture of ground meat
column3: rice
column4: leeks and some other ingredients. The word kofta is derived from Persian kūfta: in Persian
column5: kuftan (کوفتن) means "to beat" or "to grind".

Tabriz was devastated by several earthquakes during its history (e.g.

column6: some of the historical monuments have been destroyed fully or partially within construction projects (the Arg of Tabriz is in danger of destruction now
column7: because of the ongoing nearby construction project of Mosal'laye Emam). Nonetheless
column8: there are still numerous monuments remaining until now

column1: == Parks and gardens ==
Tabriz has 132 parks
column2: including 97 small parks
column3: 31 regional and 4 city parks. According to 2005 statistics
column4: the area of parks in Tabriz is 2
column6: and the area of green spaces of Tabriz is 8
column8: which is 5.6 sq.m per person. A study published in 2018 found that "Most of the urban green spaces are located on the urban fringes and in low-density higher income residential areas." It also found that "Greenspace per capita provision in Tabriz is much lower than the national and international standards (some districts offer only 0–1 sq.m. per capita green space)..." The oldest park in Tabriz
column10: was established at first Pahlavi's era in the city center. Tabriz also has 8 traveller-parks with the capacity of 10.000 travellers.

column1: Baghlar Baghi
Khaqani Park
Ghaem Magham
Golestan Park
Mashrouteh Park
Saeb Tabrizi Garden

Baghmesha Park.
== Economy ==
Tabriz is the largest economic center in Northwest Iran. The economy of Tabriz is based on commerce
column2: services
column3: health care and pharmaceutical
column4: small and heavy industries
column5: and handcrafts. Tabriz is the main site for four of Iran's Fortune 100 companies including: ITMCO
column8: Shirin Asal

column1: === Industries ===
Modern industries in Tabriz established since early 20 century by match manufacturing industries. Currently manufacturing industries in the city include manufacturing of machinery
column2: vehicles
column3: chemicals and petrochemical materials
column4: refinery
column5: cement
column8: textiles and leather
column11: and pharmaceuticals.There are hundreds of industrial complexes in Tabriz's industrial area. Among them is the Iran Tractor Manufacturing Co (ITMCO) which is one of the biggest industrial complexes in the region. This complex alone has the highest foundry and forging capacity in the Middle East and it is the biggest tractor manufacturer in Iran with several production branches within Iran and other countries. Behind ITMCO there are several other industrial complexes including Mashin Sazi Tabriz Co
column15: Tabriz Oil Refinery and a couple of industrial regions which include hundreds of small industries.

column1: Tabriz is also a site for abundant food and some of the most famous chocolate factories in Iran which honoured the city as the Chocolate City of Iran. This includes Dadash and Baradar Industrial Co. with the brand mark of Aidin
column2: Soniz which is one of the biggest factories of its kind in the region.

column1: A vast portion of the city's population is involved in small businesses like shoemaking ateliers
column2: stone-cutting
column3: furniture ateliers
column4: confectionery
column5: printing and dry nuts.

column1: === Handcrafts ateliers ===
Due to its distinct handicrafts and carpets Tabriz is selected as the world city of crafts and carpet.

Tabriz is the main centre for the production of the famous Iranian Rugs. The distinctive durability of Tabriz's carpets and its unique designs made it a famous brand in the world's carpet markets. Tabrizi rugs and carpets usually have ivory backgrounds with blue
column2: rose
column3: and indigo motifs. They often feature symmetrical and balanced designs. They usually have a single medallion that is surrounded by vines and palmettos.

column1: One of the main quality characteristics of Tabriz rugs is the weaving style
column2: using specialities that guarantee the durability of the rug in comparison for example with Kashan rugs.

column1: Other than carpets
column2: the city is famous for several other handicrafts including silverwares
column3: wood engraving
column4: pottery and ceramics
column5: Ghalamzani (Irania style of toreutics)
column8: embroider.

column1: === Shopping ===
Shopping centres are mostly located in the city centre
column2: including Grand Bazaar of Tabriz
column3: pedestrian malls on Tarbiyat street
column4: Shahnaz street and Ferdowsi street. Also
column5: there are some malls and a lot of elegant & luxurious boutiques of jewellery
column8: handicrafts
column10: home appliances and so on in the Abresan intersection
column11: Roshdiyeh district and Kouy Valiasr.The special feature of Tabriz's malls is that most of them are designated to a particular order

column1: Likewise
column2: there are seasonal/occasional shopping fairs opened mainly in the Tabriz International Exhibition Center.

column1: === Tabriz International Exhibition Center ===

Tabriz International Exhibition Center which is located in the eastern part of the city holds tens of exhibitions based on yearly schedule. The most famous fair is TEXPO which is a general trade fair. Established in 1992
column2: it usually holds exhibitions around August 4–9 every year.

column1: == Schools and libraries ==
=== Universities ===
Tabriz is the site for 14 of Iran's most prominent universities and higher education institutes. Established in 1947
column2: University of Tabriz is the most prestigious university in north-western Iran. University of Tabriz is also considered one of five mother universities in the country which works as the regional hub of science for the region. Besides University of Tabriz
column3: there are several other public universities
column4: operating in the city and its suburbs. Among them the famous ones are:

column1: Tabriz University of Medical Sciences has departments from various medical and paramedical branches. This University was part of University of Tabriz until the early 1980s.
Sahand University of Technology is established in 1989 and have majored in different fields of Engineering and Technology related sciences.
Azarbaijan University of Tarbiat Moallem is established in 1987. Azerbaijan University is a general university. Its main campus is located based in Azarshahr county.
Tabriz Islamic Arts University is a public university established in 1997.
the Payam-e Noor University of Tabriz
column2: is part of Payame Noor University network of the remote educational university.There are couple of private universities and higher educational institutes serving student as well
column3: including: Islamic Azad University of Tabriz
column4: Daneshvaran Higher Education Institute
column5: Seraj Higher Education Institute

column1: There are few technical colleges
column2: which serve the students as well: Elmi-Karbordi University of Tabriz
column3: Tabriz College of Technology
column4: Roshdiyeh Higher Education Institute of Tabriz
column5: Jahad Daneshgahi (ACECR) Higher Education Institute (East Azerbaijan Branch)
column7: State Organization of Technical and Vocational Training.

column1: There are a couple of research centers supported by Iranian government in the city including: East Azerbaijan Park of Science & Technology
column2: Islamic Azad University
column3: Science and Research Branch
column4: Tabriz.Furthermore
column5: a couple of Iranian universities have branches in Tabriz
column7: Shahid Beheshti Training Teacher Center of Tabriz.

column1: === Famous high schools ===
Hundreds of public and private schools serve students using the Iranian education system. Students attend primary school for five years
column2: middle school for three years
column3: and secondary school for a final three years. Those entering university must attend one year in college first. While the prominent language in Tabriz is Azerbaijani
column4: Persian is used in school classrooms. Some of the high schools are famous because of their history or higher educational quality.

column1: Here is a list of most famous high schools in the city:
Memorial school (American School of Tabriz) was opened in 1891 and is one of the most famous schools of American Missionary Schools in Iran. After World War II
column2: the school's name was changed to Parvin High School
column3: under Iran education ministry's management. Currently
column4: it is divided into three separate high schools
column5: and the original building is under reconstruction. Howard Baskerville used to teach in Memorial school.

column1: Roshdieh school is the first modern Iranian school
column2: which was established by Haji-Mirza Hassan Roshdieh. Currently
column3: its building is used as the Tabriz branch of the National Iranian Documents and Library Office.

column1: Vahdat Technical College is another famous school in Tabriz. It was developed by the Germans before World War II.

Ferdowsi high school is one of the largest and most prominent high schools in Tabriz. The original building was constructed by German engineers before World War II originally as a hospital with an aerial shape of H. Later on
column2: it was used as Ferdowsi high school.

column1: Mansur High School (established 1945) was one of the highest-ranking schools in Tabriz. Later on
column2: the school divided into Mansur (Taleghani) High School and Motahhari high school. The reconstruction of the school in 2010 has caused tension between alumnus of the school and administrators of the education office of Tabriz.

column1: Shahid Madani and Farzanegan or so-called Tiz-houshan high schools (which are part of SAMPAD/NODET) were established in 1989. The students are admitted to these schools through a competitive entrance exam. These schools are famous because of the higher rate of admission of their graduates through Iranian universities entrance exam.
=== Religious schools ===
Valiasr Religious School and Talebieh Islamic Science School are two major religious schools in the city which are used for teaching Islamic literature.
=== Libraries ===
Tabriz National Library
column2: also known as Central Library of Tabriz
column3: is the largest and the most famous library in the city. The Tabriz National Library has the biggest collection of classic handwritten Persian literature in the northwest region of Iran. There are many other public libraries all around the city such as Tarbiat library
column4: Helal Ahmar
column5: Shahid Motahhari
column8: and Farhangsara.

column1: == Infrastructure ==
=== Health systems ===
The Ministry of Health operates most of the public hospitals and health centres in the Tabriz metropolitan region
column2: some of which are aligned with the Tabriz Medical School.

column1: === Transportation ===
Tabriz residents mostly commute by public bus
column2: shuttle taxis
column3: metro
column4: bike
column5: and personal cars. Tabriz public bus lines connect its districts and some of its suburbs to the city centre of Tabriz. Tabriz also has a Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) line which runs through an 18 km (11 mi) from Train Station in West of Tabriz to Baseej Square in far East of the city.

column1: Tabriz also has a public shuttle taxi service which connects city centres to major districts of the city. There is another taxi service running in the city calls Telephone Taxi which operates by private companies.

Part of Tabriz subway line 1 is operational since 2015 which goes from Shahgoli to Shahriyar. Several lines are planned to connect districts of Tabriz to its city center however the construction is six years behind the schedule. The government of Iran had planned to finish 6 km (4 mi) of line No.1 of the network in 2006
column2: but this was not achieved due to financial problems and currently only half of the track for the metro line has been laid.Tabriz is linked to Europe through Turkey's roads and Bazargan (Azerbaijani
column3: Persian: بازرگان ) border. Tabriz is connected to Tehran by Freeway 2 (Iran).

column1: The city is linked to Iran National Railways (IRIR
column2: Persian: رجا ) also to Europe by Turkey's railways via Ghotour (Azerbaijani
column3: Persian قطور) bridge in West Azerbaijan province of Iran. Tabriz was the first city in Iran to be served by railways with the construction of the Tabriz-Jolfa line in 1912–1914 (later converted to broad-gauge in 1916). Tabriz Railway Station is located in the western part of the city
column4: at the end of Khomeyni Street.

column1: Tabriz International Airport opened in 1950 and is the only international airport in East Azerbaijan (since 1991). It has daily and weekly domestic flights to Tehran
column2: Isfahan
column3: Kish Island
column4: Shiraz
column5: and Mashhad. It also has daily and weekly flights to Istanbul

column1: == Sports ==
Tabriz is a hub for the major sports events in the region. The city has a couple of sports complexes. The major sports complex inside the city is Bagh Shomal complex which includes a soccer stadium
column2: swimming pool
column3: an arena for basketball and volleyball. There is also a bigger sports complex which is named the Olympic village which has a soccer stadium and a cycling track. They are several other smaller complexes for martial arts
column4: swimming pools
column5: and gymnasiums. Among many different sports activities soccer and cycling got more attention because of the cities teams and international events which are held in the city.

column1: === Football ===
Football is a major part of the city's culture. The huge number of fans made Tabriz home to two Iranian major Football teams: Tractor
column2: and Machine Sazi FC.

column1: Tractor and Machine Sazi play in the Iran Pro League. Tractor is very popular in northwestern Iran. The home stadium for Tractor is the city's major stadium
column2: Sahand Stadium which has the capacity of 80
column3: 000 people and Machine Sazi plays in its own 15
column4: 000 seated Stadium.

column1: In June 1976 Bagh Shomal Stadium of Tabriz hosted part of the final tournament of the AFC Asian Cup games.
=== Futsal ===

The city's main futsal club is Dabiri Tabriz which was founded in 1998 and plays at the Oloum Pezeshki Arena in the city. The club won the Iranian Futsal Super League in 2014 and finished third in Asia. The cities other futsal team is Shahrdari Tabriz who play at the larger Shahid Poursharifi Arena. The club is usually a mid-table team and has less support throughout the city.
=== Cycling ===

Tabriz is also home for Azerbaijan Cycling Tour which is held on a yearly based calendar since 1986. This cycling tour is the most prestigious cycling tour in Iran. Tabriz is also home for Tabriz Petrochemical Cycling Team
column2: a cycling team which is competing in UCI-sanctioned competitions through Asian continents.

column1: Sahand and Yam ski resorts are located in an hour drive from Tabriz. Depending on the perception
column2: both resorts start operation from late December till early March.

column1: == Media ==

Tabriz has one state television channel called Sahand TV that broadcasts in both Persian and Azerbaijani languages. It broadcasts internationally through the Arabsat and Intelsat satellites.The city has one government-controlled radio channel broadcasting in both Persian and Azerbaijani languages.The 14 weekly magazines and 8 main newspapers published in the city include: Amin
column2: Mahd Azadi
column3: Asr Azadi
column4: Fajr Azarbaijan
column5: Saeb Tabriz

column2: Tabriz was always the origin for many Iranian illumination and modernization movements. This is why the city was the hometown of numerous Iranian dominant figures including many Iranian politicians

column4: artists
column5: and military leaders. Here a partial list of some of the most notable people who born or lived in Tabriz.

Tabriz is twinned with:
== Consulates ==

Azerbaijan and Turkey have consulate offices in Tabriz. Formerly the Soviet Union and the United States had consulate offices in Tabriz. The US consulate office closed after the 1979 Islamic revolution and the USSR's office closed after the collapse of the USSR in 1991.
